description: Write a function that checks if a command string contains shell metacharacters (;, |, &, $, `, \, ", ', <, >, \n). Return true if dangerous characters found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Dangerous): hasShellMetacharacters("ls; rm -rf /") -> true. Example (Safe): hasShellMetacharacters("ls -la") -> false.

Write a function that sanitizes a command argument by removing or escaping dangerous characters. Return a sanitized string, or empty string on error. Must handle empty strings safely. Example: sanitizeArgument("file; rm -rf") -> "file_rm_-rf" or similar safe output.

Write a function that checks if a command matches any entry in an allowlist vector. Return true if allowed, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Allowed): isCommandAllowed("ls", allowlist) -> true. Example (Denied): isCommandAllowed("rm", allowlist) -> false.

Write a function that checks if a command argument contains path traversal sequences like '..' or absolute paths. Return true if dangerous, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Dangerous): hasPathTraversal("../../etc/passwd") -> true. Example (Safe): hasPathTraversal("file.txt") -> false.

Write a function that builds a command vector for safe execution from a command and arguments. Return a vector of strings, or empty vector on error. Must validate all arguments. Example: buildCommandVector("ls", {"-la", "/home"}) -> {"ls", "-la", "/home"}.

Write a function that validates a filename argument to be used in a command. Return true if valid (alphanumerics, dots, hyphens, underscores only), false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Valid): isValidFilenameArg("report_2024.txt") -> true. Example (Invalid): isValidFilenameArg("file; rm -rf") -> false.

Write a function that checks if a command contains redirection operators (<, >, >>). Return true if found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Found): hasRedirection("ls > output.txt") -> true. Example (Not Found): hasRedirection("ls -la") -> false.

Write a function that checks if a command contains pipe operators (|). Return true if found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Found): hasPipe("ls | grep test") -> true. Example (Not Found): hasPipe("ls -la") -> false.

Write a function that checks if a command contains command substitution syntax ($(...) or `...`). Return true if found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Found): hasCommandSubstitution("echo $(whoami)") -> true. Example (Not Found): hasCommandSubstitution("echo hello") -> false.

Write a function that escapes a shell argument by wrapping it in single quotes and escaping any embedded single quotes. Return an escaped string, or empty string on error. Must handle empty strings safely. Example: escapeShellArg("file's name") -> "'file'\''s name'".

Write a function that safely splits a command string into tokens (command and arguments). Return a vector of tokens, or empty vector on error. Must handle quotes properly. Example: splitCommand("ls -la /home") -> {"ls", "-la", "/home"}.

Write a function that checks if a command length is within safe limits. Return true if valid, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Valid): isCommandLengthValid("ls -la", 1024) -> true. Example (Too Long): isCommandLengthValid(<1025-char command>, 1024) -> false.

Write a function that checks if a command matches any entry in a blocklist vector. Return true if blocked, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Blocked): isCommandBlocked("rm", blocklist) -> true. Example (Allowed): isCommandBlocked("ls", blocklist) -> false.

Write a function that extracts the command name (first token) from a command string. Return the command name, or empty string on error. Must handle leading whitespace. Example: extractCommandName("  ls -la  ") -> "ls".

Write a function that checks if a command contains semicolons (;), which can chain commands. Return true if found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Found): hasSemicolon("ls; rm file") -> true. Example (Not Found): hasSemicolon("ls -la") -> false.

Write a function that checks if a command contains ampersands (&), which can run commands in background. Return true if found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Found): hasAmpersand("sleep 10 &") -> true. Example (Not Found): hasAmpersand("ls -la") -> false.

Write a function that validates an argument against a safe pattern (e.g., alphanumerics and specific safe characters). Return true if valid, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Valid): matchesArgumentPattern("file_123.txt") -> true. Example (Invalid): matchesArgumentPattern("file; rm") -> false.

Write a function that checks if a command contains variable expansion syntax ($VAR or ${VAR}). Return true if found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Found): hasVariableExpansion("echo $HOME") -> true. Example (Not Found): hasVariableExpansion("echo hello") -> false.

Write a function that removes shell comments (everything after #) from a command. Return the cleaned command, or empty string on error. Must handle empty strings safely. Example: removeComments("ls -la # list files") -> "ls -la ".

Write a function that checks if a command contains newline characters (\n), which can inject multiple commands. Return true if found, false otherwise. Must handle empty strings safely. Example (Found): hasNewline("ls\nrm file") -> true. Example (Not Found): hasNewline("ls -la") -> false.
